channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Pope Francis Writes to Catholics Worldwide Over Sexual Abuse
item.media:description: Pope Francis at the Vatican on Sunday. A letter issued on Monday may have been the first time a pope has addressed the world’s 1.2 billion Catholics about sexual abuse, a Vatican spokesman said.
item.description: “We showed no care for the little ones; we abandoned them,” the pope wrote in a letter urging all 1.2 billion Catholics to fight the culture that had enabled abuse.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Kim Jong-un Focuses on Economy as Nuclear Talks With U.S. Stall
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, left, inspecting the construction of a hydroelectric power plant in North Hamgyong Province, North Korea, in an undated photograph provided by the official Korean Central News Agency last month.
item.description: North Korea’s leader is lashing out against economic missteps as he turns his attention to building prosperity. But he needs American cooperation.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Korean Families, Separated for 6 Decades, Are Briefly Reunited
item.media:description: Lee Gyum-sum, 92, of South Korea wrapped her arms around her son Ri Sang-chol, a 71-year-old North Korean, for the first time in more than 60 years.
item.description: Relatives who live on opposite sides of the inter-Korean border were able to meet for the first time since fighting ended in 1953, in a new round of reunions intended to be a show of good will.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Israel’s Latest Culture War Plays Out Under the Wedding Canopy
item.media:description: Shiran Abukasis (center), 30, and Julia Klein (center right), 24, jump into the pool during their wedding party, in Hadera, Israel last month.
item.media:credit: Corinna Kern for The New York Times
item.description: Rejecting the strictly Orthodox monopoly over marriage and divorce, Israeli Jews increasingly opt for alternative weddings.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Emaciated by Cancer and Mistaken as a Drug Addict, Filipino Dies in Detention
item.media:description: The wake of Allan Rafael in Caloocan city, Philippines, this month.
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.description: When police in the Philippines arrested Allan Rafael, he explained he looked sick because of chemotherapy not narcotics. His death in custody has outraged a loyal constituency of President Duterte.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: Two More Earthquakes Hit Indonesian Island, Killing More Than a Dozen
item.media:description: Makeshift hospitals like this one have sprung up across the Indonesian island of Lombok after a series of devastating earthquakes.
item.description: The earthquakes come as the region was still recovering from an Aug. 5 quake that killed 460 people and wiped out whole villages.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Australian Prime Minister Abandons Climate Targets, Bowing to Party Pressure
item.media:description: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull of Australia, center, with Treasurer Scott Morrison, left, and Josh Frydenberg, the minister for environment and energy, at the Parliament House in Canberra on Monday.
item.description: On Monday, Malcolm Turnbull announced he would delay a climate and energy policy that divided senior figures in the Australian government.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE and ISABELLA KWAI

item.title: As Taliban Start Charm Offensive, Afghan President Calls for Cease-Fire
item.media:description: Damaged shops after a Taliban attack in Ghazni city, Afghanistan, this month.
item.description: The Taliban have been courting civilians for weeks and promising not to harm soldiers who surrender, raising hopes of a cease-fire in Afghanistan. On Sunday, the government made the first move.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and FAHIM ABED
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: ‘All of Africa Is Here’: Where Europe’s Southern Border Is Just a Fence
item.media:description: A view of Jebel Musa, a mountain in Morocco that towers over the Spanish enclave of Ceuta.
item.media:credit: Ksenia Kuleshova for The New York Times
item.description: Ceuta, a Spanish enclave on Morocco’s coast, is surrounded by a double 20-foot fence topped with barbed wire, the latest flash point for Europe-bound migrants.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: After 60 Years, a Bank Robber Returns to the Crime Scene. This Time, Just for a Drink.
item.media:description: Boyne Lester Johnston, who was described in a 1958 wanted poster as a “neat dresser” and “champagne drinker,” raised a glass 60 years later at the scene of his bank heist in Ottawa.
item.description: Boyne Lester Johnston stole 260,000 Canadian dollars from a bank in Ottawa in 1958. This month, he sipped Champagne at the bank, now a hip restaurant.
item.dc:creator: SARAH MERVOSH

item.title: Netflix Tests Promotional Videos but Users See ‘Commercials’
item.media:description: Some Netflix subscribers on social media complained about what they said were commercials. The company said the interruptions were videos promoting other content on the streaming service.
item.description: An experiment by Netflix to highlight some of its shows with promotional videos was met with resistance from viewers who disliked the interruptions.
item.dc:creator: SANDRA E. GARCIA

item.title: Favorite Place: My Armenia
item.media:description: A summer evening in Yerevan’s Republic Square.
item.media:credit: Danielle Villasana for The New York Times
item.description: A poet returns to his ancestral country where, after the recent “velvet revolution,” the sense of a new era is palpable.
item.dc:creator: PETER BALAKIAN

item.title: International Herald Tribune: 1918: Germans No Longer Believe in Victory
item.media:description: A German soldier told Americans that his compatriots had given up expectation of victory in World War I.
item.description: A German soldier who had wandered into enemy lines told Americans that his compatriots had given up expectation of victory but would continue to fight.
item.dc:creator: THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: Greece’s Bailout Is Ending. The Pain Is Far From Over.
item.media:description: Tourists at the Parthenon in Athens. Tourism in Greece has spiked in recent years, creating jobs and economic growth.
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.description: As a new era of financial independence beckons, more than a third of the population is in poverty, unemployment remains high and wages have tumbled.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: Residents of Brazil Border Town Attack Camps for Venezuelan Migrants
item.media:description: Venezuelans waited at a bus terminal in Santa Elena, Venezuela, on Sunday after being expelled by Brazilians from a border control point in the northern Brazil town of Pacaraima.
item.description: As Brazilians in the northern town of Pacaraima set fire to their tents, hundreds of Venezuelans ran back across the border.
item.dc:creator: MANUELA ANDREONI

item.title: More Earthquakes Strike an Indonesian Island, Cutting Power and Spreading Panic
item.media:description: Patients at a hospital ward on Lombok Island in Indonesia on Monday. The island has suffered a series of powerful earthquakes over the past few weeks.
item.description: The island of Lombok, which endured a deadly earthquake two weeks ago, sustained a series of serious tremors on Sunday that resulted in one death
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Taiwan President Stops in U.S. as Relations Warm, Angering China
item.media:description: President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan in Paraguay earlier this month, after a stopover in Los Angeles.
item.description: President Tsai Ing-wen, over Chinese objections, made two brief stopovers in the last week, meeting with members of Congress who favor closer ties.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS HORTON
item.category: Reagan, Ronald, Presidential Library and Museum
Center for Strategic and International Studies
American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research

item.title: Pregnant Minister Cycles to Hospital to Give Birth
item.description: Julie Anne Genter, New Zealand’s minister for women’s affairs, posted photographs on social media of her “mostly downhill” trip to a hospital, where she was due to have labor induced.
item.dc:creator: CHARLOTTE GRAHAM-McLAY

item.title: Croatia Dispatch: Throngs Enticed by ‘Game of Thrones’ Threaten a Magical City
item.media:description: Tourists in Dubrovnik, Croatia, on the old town’s fortress wall, which appears in the hit show “Game of Thrones.” The coastal fort dates from the 13th century.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: Dubrovnik, Croatia, known to “Game of Thrones” fans as King’s Landing, is a fantasy made real. As crowds of “set-jetters” threaten to spoil the port’s sublime majesty, officials are fighting back.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA

item.title: As Fighting Escalates, U.N. Urges Protection for Aid Workers in Afghanistan
item.media:description: Afghan internally displaced people receiving food rations distributed by the Turkish Disaster and Emergency Management Authority in Herat, Afghanistan, this week.
item.description: With 23 aid workers killed, ambulances caught in crossfire, U.N. asks for protection to deliver aid to civilians suffering the brunt of war and drought.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Who Is Winning the War in Afghanistan? Depends on Which One
item.media:description: Devastation in Ghazni. Hundreds of bodies were abandoned in the streets or dumped in the river during recent fighting.
item.description: A New York Times correspondent who has reported on Afghanistan since the 1979 Soviet invasion offers observations on the war that began in 2001.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: The Bride Was a Dream in a Dirndl, but Putin Stole the Show
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia danced with Foreign Minister Karin Kneissl of Austria during her wedding on Saturday.
item.description: Vladimir Putin stopped by the Austrian foreign minister’s wedding to wish her well amid criticism from the opposition and abroad.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: ‘A Wound to the Heart of Genoa’: Italy Buries Victims of Bridge Collapse
item.media:description: Relatives mourned some of the victims of the collapsed Morandi highway bridge in Genoa, Italy, before the state funeral on Saturday.
item.description: The country declared a day of national mourning as it struggled to come to terms with a tragedy that critics say could have been avoided.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Imran Khan Takes Oath in Pakistan, a Nation Divided and in Debt
item.media:description: Imran Khan at a session of the National Assembly in Islamabad, Pakistan, on Friday, when he was made prime minister with 51 percent of the vote.
item.media:credit: Pakistan's Press Information Department, via EPA
item.description: The new prime minister will have to overcome deep political divisions to pursue economic reforms as the country’s debt payments come due.
item.dc:creator: MARIA ABI-HABIB and SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Quebec’s ‘Trash Radio’ Host Fires Up Outrage, and Big Ratings
item.media:description: Jeff Fillion in his radio studio in Quebec City.
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times
item.description: Jeff Fillion, among the most prominent talk radio hosts in Quebec City, says he was “doing my thing 20 years before Trump arrived.”
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Kofi Annan, Who Redefined the U.N., Dies at 80
item.media:description: Mr. Annan in Liquisa, East Timor, in 2000. The United Nations worked to restore stability to East Timor after it declared independence from Indonesia.
item.description: Awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2001, he projected himself and his organization as the world’s conscience and moral arbiter, despite a series of failures and scandals.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: France Dispatch: Catalan Gypsies, Unique and Embattled, Resist as Homes Are Reduced to Rubble
item.media:description: The Gypsies of Perpignan have been in the area since the Middle Ages, when Saint Jacques was built with a narrow grid of houses huddled protectively against one another.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: Angered by the demolition of many of the historical buildings where they live in France, an impoverished community of outsiders protested and officials backed down. But the truce is only temporary.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Truth-Testing Trump’s 250-Plus Attacks on the Russia Inquiry
item.media:description: President Trump at Trump National Golf Club in Bedminster, N.J. last week.
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: We assessed President Trump’s claims about Russia’s interference in the 2016 election and the ensuing federal investigation of his campaign.
item.dc:creator: LINDA QIU
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Merkel and Putin Sound Pragmatic Notes After Years of Tension
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Saturday at Meseberg palace, outside Berlin.
item.description: The Russian president called on Germany’s help in rebuilding Syria so refugees can return to the war-devastated country.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Murder Mystery in Ancient Monastery Reverberates in Coptic Church
item.media:description: A monk entering a cell at the Monastery of St. Pishoy, a few miles from where a bishop was killed.
item.description: The death of Bishop Epiphanius, found in a pool of blood, has exposed simmering tensions in the cloistered world of Egypt’s ancient desert monasteries.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Hairy Mountain Beasts and Franglais Humor: The Canada Letter
item.media:description: Todd Standing in camouflage while sasquatch tracking.
item.description: The sasquatch gets its day in court and Montreal’s multilingual comedian.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Trump, Elon Musk, Turkey: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JOUMANA KHATIB and HIROKO MASUIKE

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Empowering Teenage Girls in a Traditional Village and Across Morocco
item.media:description: Maryam Montague, who started a program to empower girls in Morocco.
item.media:credit: Natalie Keyssar for The New York Times
item.description: Maryam Montague, a former humanitarian aid worker turned social entrepreneur, is inspiring girls to stay in school in a place where many drop out at puberty to marry.
item.dc:creator: MARJORIE OLSTER

item.title: ‘I Would Have Died There’: Floods in Kerala, India, Kill Hundreds
item.description: Heavy rains have caused some of the region’s worst flooding in nearly a century, killing more than 300 people and displacing thousands.

item.title: Imran Khan, Elected as Prime Minister, Offers Little Conciliation to Foes
item.media:description: Imran Khan offered little conciliation to his political opponents after being elected prime minister on Friday.
item.description: An acrimonious vote in Parliament may be a prelude to the difficult path ahead for the new prime minister, who repeated his anti-corruption campaign theme in a brief speech.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Erdogan to Turkey: The West Is Waging ‘Economic War’
item.media:description: Since his re-election in June to a newly powerful presidency, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has become the dominant communicator of his government to Turkey’s 81 million people.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: Turkey’s president turns American actions against Turkey to his advantage, appealing to national pride and deflecting responsibility for the lira’s collapse.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: King of Spain Leads Ceremony to Remember Barcelona Attack Victims
item.media:description: Hundreds of people gathered on Friday on Las Ramblas, the main promenade in Barcelona, Spain, to pay tribute to the people killed in a terrorist attack one year ago.
item.description: The anniversary commemorations were designed to set aside tensions over independence for Catalonia. But politics crept in.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: China Fires 10 Officials Over Bad Vaccines as Anger Mounts
item.media:description: A child receiving a vaccination in Jiujiang, China, last month. Many parents said they were skeptical of the government’s vow to clean up the vaccine industry.
item.description: President Xi Jinping is trying to quell a national outcry over the scandal and restore confidence in the health care system.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China

item.title: Kerala Flooding: Hundreds Killed in Indian State’s Worst Rains Since 1920s
item.media:description: Some residents were rescued using inflatable boats, but others were forced to cling to anything that could float.
item.description: The floods have left at least 324 people dead, and hundreds of thousands more have been made homeless.
item.dc:creator: MARIA ABI-HABIB

item.title: 5 Takeaways From Elon Musk’s Interview With The Times About Tesla
item.media:description: In a wide-ranging interview with The New York Times, Elon Musk spoke of the heavy toll that running Tesla has taken on his personal life.
item.description: The Tesla chief executive addressed a wide range of issues, including the search for a chief operating officer and his tweet that sent the company’s shares soaring.
item.dc:creator: PRASHANT S. RAO

item.title: Britain’s Big Squeeze: As Austerity Helps Bankrupt an English County, Even Conservatives Mutiny
item.media:description: Higham Ferrers is one of the towns that will be affected by the de-facto bankruptcy of the Conservative-led Northamptonshire County Council, in England.
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.description: The local government in an affluent part of England is out of cash, and others may follow. Its former leader blames funding cuts from London.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Life in Turkey Now: Tough Talk, but Fears of Drug Shortages
item.media:description: A new mosque under construction in Taksim Square.
item.media:credit: Danielle Villasana for The New York Times
item.description: The lira’s plunge, exacerbated by a dispute with the U.S. over a detained pastor, has exposed growing economic pressures that some economists say could be near a breaking point.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING

item.title: North Korea Presses Demand for End of War Amid Talk of Pompeo Visit
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, second from left, was met by Foreign Minister Ri Yong Ho and other North Korean officials at the airport in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, last month.
item.description: South Korea’s leader indicated that Secretary of State Mike Pompeo was preparing for his fourth visit to the North.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: In Shadow of Mt. Etna, Europe Makes a Last Stand for Solar
item.media:description: The new, more efficient solar panel being tested by an Italian utility, Enel, at a Sicilian factory in Catania.
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.description: Europe was an early backer of solar power technology. But its panel manufacturing has fallen off, and China has emerged as the dominant force.
item.dc:creator: STANLEY REED and KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Turkish Airstrike in Iraqi Territory Kills a Kurdish Militant Leader
item.media:description: Fighters of the Kurdistan Workers’ Party, also known as the P.K.K., patrolling in the Qandil Mountains, near their headquarters in northern Iraq, in June.
item.description: The attack killed Zaki Shingali, a leader of a group that Turkey calls a terrorist organization, but he was considered a hero to the Yazidi minority in Iraq for his efforts to help them.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Cut in Two, Genoa Finds Its Political Paralysis Now Eclipsed by Shock
item.media:description: The Morandi Bridge that collapsed in Genoa, Italy, this week was built so close to homes that residents could not sleep at night when workers did maintenance work.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: The collapsed bridge illuminates the larger issue of Italy’s difficulty in making strategic decisions, which leads to immobility.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI, ELISABETTA POVOLEDO and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: Dream of a Better Life in Afghanistan Ends in a Hilltop Grave for Students
item.media:description: Mourners carried the body of one of the young victims of a suicide attack at a university prep center during a burial ceremony on Thursday in Kabul, Afghanistan.
item.description: The students left villages for the capital city to pursue an education and lift themselves and their families out of poverty. A suicide bombing ended all that.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and FATIMA FAIZI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: ‘Dr. Bumbum,’ Brazilian Plastic Surgeon, Is Charged in Patient’s Death
item.media:description: Denis Furtado in Rio de Janeiro last month. He has been charged in the death of one of his patients.
item.description: The celebrity surgeon, known as Dr. Bumbum, performed a buttock lift. The case has stirred concerns in a country seen as hooked on beauty.
item.dc:creator: MANUELA ANDREONI and SHASTA DARLINGTON
